Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2002 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: Formosa Plastics Corp., Texas, and Formosa Plastics Corp., Louisiana, agreed to spend more than $10 million on pollution controls to address air, water, and hazardous waste violations at two petrochemical plants in Point Comfort, Texas, and Baton Rouge, La. The companies also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $2.8 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: To settle a suit involving vinyl chloride emissions at its Delaware City facility, Formosa Plastics agreed to take steps to comply with environmental regulations, pay a $450,000 penalty, and take additional measures including an $840,000 project that exceeds federal and state legal requirements.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control
Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control
Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: This Order gave the Company the choice of paying $40,000 (plus $6,000 cost recovery) as penalty or paying $20,000 (plus $6,000 cost recovery) plus implementing a $40,000 environmental improvement project to upgrade valves to avoid future releases. The order addressed three VCM releases, three inprocess wastewater releases, two visible emissions exceedances, and a pair of failed stack tests for hydrogen chloride.
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: The US EPA was the plaintiff and the State of Delaware was a plaintiff intervenor. In addition to the $450,000 penalty split evenly between the EPA and Delaware, this decree includes the establishment of stipulated penalties, a supplemental environmental project (valued at $842,847), injunctive relief, a goal to reduce the annual RVCM average to 550 ppm (excluding seed resin) within 3 years, and an immediate reduction in the annual average RVCM limit to 750 ppm (excluding seed resin).
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control
Notes: Penalty listed is the state's share of penalty plus entire Supplemental Environmental Project spending.

Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: Formosa Plastics agreed to pay a $300,000 penalty and spend about $4 million on plant improvements and environmental projects.
Info Source: Formosa Settles Violations at Baton Rouge Plant, Chemical Week, October 23, 2002 (via Nexis).

Agency: South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on October 22, 2020 in response to an open records request.

Agency: South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control

Description: Formosa Plastics Corporation agreed to pay $2.85 million in civil penalties and to improve its risk management program to resolve alleged violations of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions of the Clean Air Act (CAA) at its petrochemical manufacturing plant in Point Comfort, Texas.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
